Please don't change any code yet.
Could you convert this plan into a speckit spec with a plan.md, tasks.md and spec.md file you can name it what you think is most suitable
do we need to clarify more or is this spec eduquest-api-v2-migration ready to be implemented?

I got this could you review and update the spec and show me the last version but don't change code yet. • Your eduquest-api-v2-migration spec is very close and broadly correct. A few targeted fixes/clarifications will reduce risk.

  ## Review / fixes

  - Progress endpoint path
      - Your spec uses POST /api/courses/{courseId}/progress (good). Keep it exactly that; it’s the same one used by the v2 player.
  - currentIndex
      - Do not assume order == currentIndex.
      - In v2 progress, currentIndex is the player’s “position in visible items”, while order is an authoring sort key on items. They often align, but they don’t have to.
      - For the Luanti game, safest is: send a monotonic local integer (0,1,2,…) representing “how many questions attempted in this session/course”, or just send 0 always if you don’t need resume behavior in the
        game. The backend mainly cares about itemId + selectedAnswer.
  - completed
      - Treat completed as optional “course finished” state. If you can’t reliably compute it, send false always.
      - Your current plan to compute completed=true when no unseen eligible items remain for that course is reasonable, but only if you scope selection per-course.
  - Mixing courses
      - Your new endpoint returns questions only from active courses and returns unanswered first, else wrong. It may return items from multiple active courses.
      - For the game UX, pick one policy:
          - A) Mix across all active courses (simpler, but completed becomes ambiguous)
          - B) Stick to one course at a time (recommended; makes completed meaningful and reduces cognitive switching)
  - Answered/unseen logic
      - Yes: selectedAnswer != null in questionItems should be treated as authoritative, because it comes from server progress.
      - Keep local storage as a fallback for offline/temporary suppression.
  - Credit endpoint auth
      - In this repo, /api/student/credit/get is protected by /api/ prefix, so it should use the same Bearer token. (If you’re calling server.eduquest.vip, it should be consistent with the other authenticated
        endpoints.)

  ## Answers to the open questions

  - Does order equal currentIndex expected by /progress?
    Not guaranteed. Prefer sending a safe value (0 or a local counter); backend correctness mainly hinges on itemId + selectedAnswer.
  - What constitutes completed=true?
    Best treated as “course done”. If your game doesn’t implement course progression, send false always. If you do one-course-at-a-time selection, you can set true when no unseen eligible items remain for that
    course.
  - Restrict to one course or mix all questionItems?
    Recommended: one course at a time (simpler correctness and completion semantics). Mixing is fine if you always send completed=false.

  ## Is the spec ready to implement?

  Yes, with one small decision recorded explicitly:

  - Choose course mixing policy (one-course-at-a-time vs mix), and
  - Decide how you’ll populate currentIndex and whether you ever set completed=true.

  If you tell me which of those two policies you want (A or B), I can suggest the exact wording to add to the spec for clarity.


› Can we choose this : one-course-at-a-time and then can you update your advice


• Yes—choosing one-course-at-a-time makes the integration cleaner. Updated guidance:

  - Selection policy
      - Pick a single courseId as the “current course” (persist it in mod storage).
      - Only select questions where questionItem.courseId == currentCourseId.
      - When the current course has no eligible unseen questions left, rotate to the next course (or refetch).
  - currentIndex
      - Don’t use order as currentIndex.
      - Use a simple per-course counter stored locally: currentIndex = attemptsCountForCourse (0,1,2,...). This matches the “resume position” idea without requiring item-order alignment.
  - completed
      - Now it has a clear meaning: “this course is done in the game”.
      - Set completed=true only when there are no remaining eligible unseen questions for that courseId after marking the current one answered.
      - Otherwise keep completed=false.
  - Answered/unseen
      - Still prefer server truth: selectedAnswer != null means answered.
      - Use local storage as fallback/offline suppression.
  - Course rotation
      - If /api/v2/questions/active returns multiple courses, choose the first course that has at least one eligible unseen item and set it as currentCourseId.
      - If none have unseen, you’re in the “practice wrong” phase (the endpoint will return wrong items when unanswered is empty). You can either:
          - continue same course and practice wrong, or
          - declare completion and stop/celebrate.

  If you want, I can also suggest a tiny deterministic course-pick rule (e.g., lowest UUID, or last played) so behavior is stable between sessions.


› Yes please :   If you want, I can also suggest a tiny deterministic course-pick rule (e.g., lowest UUID, or last played) so behavior is stable between sessions.


• Deterministic “one-course-at-a-time” selection rules that work well:

  ## Recommended rule (stable + user-friendly)

  1. If currentCourseId is saved locally and still appears in data.courses → keep using it.
  2. Else pick the course with the most eligible unseen questions (computed from questionItems for that course).
  3. Tie-breaker: pick the course with the most recent updatedAt (if provided), else lowest UUID string.

  This keeps the “current course” sticky, but also ensures you don’t get stuck on a course with no playable questions.

  ## Simpler rule (easy to implement)

  1. If saved currentCourseId still exists → use it.
  2. Else pick the course with the lowest UUID (string compare).
  3. If that course has no eligible unseen questions, pick the next lowest, etc.

  ## Persistence keys (suggested)

  - eduquest.current_course_id
  - eduquest.course_attempt_counter.<courseId> (for currentIndex)
  - eduquest.answered.<courseId>:<itemId> (local fallback)

  If you want the least moving parts: use the simpler rule. If you want best UX: use the recommended rule.

 
› I like the recommended rule
